intro: Acanthocereus pentagonus, commonly known as the night blooming cactus, is a flowering plant native to Mexico. It is characterized by its cylindrical stems covered in sharp, spiny areoles. The plant produces large, fragrant white flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as bats and moths. It thrives in arid environments and requires minimal water, making it well adapted to desert conditions. The species is popular among cactus enthusiasts for its unique appearance and nighttime blooming habit.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthocereus pentagonus is primarily native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is found in states such as Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas, as well as in parts of Sonora and Sinaloa. This cactus thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and desert plains. It is commonly seen in desert regions with low rainfall and high sunlight exposure. The plant is well adapted to withstand extreme temperatures and limited water availability.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthocereus pentagonus was mainly introduced to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is commonly found in desert environments, particularly in areas with well-drained soils. This plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its distinctive blue-gray foliage and showy yellow flowers.
